Problem:
Consider a system characterized by the integral equation \\(y(t) = \\int_0^t e^{A(t-s)} B u(s) ds\\), where A and B are constant matrices and \\(u(t)\\) is an input function altering the state. We examine the effect of a transformation defined by the function \\(f(u) = Cu\\), where C is a constant matrix transformation applied to the input.

If the transformation \\(f(u)\\) is applied to \\(u(s)\\) from s = 0 to T, without other interventions, will the function \\(y(t)\\) at t = T be the same as if \\(u(s)\\) was directly used to compute \\(y(t)\\) without transformation?
Explanation: Applying transformation \\(f(u) = Cu\\) modifies the input, hence the convolution integral changes due to different integrand \\(e^{A(t-s)} B Cu(s)\\). Since C influences the form of \\(u(s)\\), the resulting \\(y(t)\\) will differ.

causal_map_integration: Applying the transformation \(f(u) = Cu\) to the input \(u(s)\) from \(s = 0\) to \(T\) changes the input used to compute \(y(t)\) at \(t = T\), thus \(y(t)\) at \(t = T\) will be different if the transformation is applied compared to using \(u(s)\) directly.
